course.title: American History I
course.subtitle: To 1865
course.description: Survey of American history from pre-Columbian times through the Civil War, emphasizing social, political, and economic development.

clos.text: Analyze the social, political, and economic development of the United States from pre-Columbian times through 1865
Evaluate how diverse groups (Native Americans, Europeans, Africans, women) shaped American society and institutions
Apply historical thinking skills to interpret primary and secondary sources
Communicate historical arguments effectively through written and visual projects

historicalThinkingSkills.name: Source Analysis
historicalThinkingSkills.description: Distinguish primary from secondary sources, evaluate credibility, identify bias

historicalThinkingSkills.name: Chronological Reasoning
historicalThinkingSkills.description: Sequence events, identify cause-effect relationships, understand periodization

historicalThinkingSkills.name: Contextualization
historicalThinkingSkills.description: Situate events within broader historical, geographic, and cultural contexts

historicalThinkingSkills.name: Comparison
historicalThinkingSkills.description: Compare historical developments across time, space, and groups

historicalThinkingSkills.name: Data Literacy
historicalThinkingSkills.description: Interpret quantitative historical evidence (charts, graphs, maps, statistics)

programScaffolding.description: How HIS-131 connects to other history courses and program-level goals

programGoals.text: Demonstrate critical thinking through historical analysis
Evaluate diverse perspectives and cultural contexts
Apply information literacy skills to primary and secondary sources
Communicate historical arguments effectively in writing
Engage civic responsibility through understanding of historical change

modules.title: Indigenous America & First Contact
inquiryQuestions: Who lived in the Americas before 1492, and how did they organize their societies?
What happened when Europeans, Africans, and Indigenous peoples first encountered each other?
How did disease shape the outcomes of European colonization more than military conquest?

mlos.text: Describe pre-Columbian Indigenous civilizations and their diverse societies
Analyze the effects of the Columbian Exchange on Indigenous and European populations
Evaluate the role of Spanish colonialism in creating new racial hierarchies

content.title: IC1: Indigenous America
content.description: Pre-Columbian civilizations, diverse Indigenous societies, agricultural innovations

content.title: IC2: European Exploration
content.description: Causes of exploration, technological advances, different European approaches

content.title: IC3: First Contact & Columbian Exchange
content.description: Disease devastation, Spanish conquest, creation of racial hierarchies

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 key historical terms with their correct definitions. Terms include Columbian Exchange, Cahokia, Encomienda, Mestizaje, and more. You have 2 attempts and 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: People & Events
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 multiple-choice questions about key people and events from Indigenous America through First Contact. You have 2 attempts and 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Timeline Builder OR Comparison Activity
activities.studentInstructions: Choose between Timeline Builder (sort events into time periods) or Comparison Activity (analyze differences between Indigenous societies). You have 2 attempts and 25 minutes.

modules.title: Colonial Development
inquiryQuestions: How did English colonists transform fluid racial categories into fixed legal systems of slavery?
What role did religious and political conflicts in Britain play in shaping colonial development?
How did different groups resist or adapt to European colonization?

mlos.text: Explain the development of race-based slavery in British North America
Analyze colonial rebellions and resistance movements (Bacon's Rebellion, Pueblo Revolt)
Evaluate the impact of the Great Awakening and consumer revolution on colonial identity

content.title: IC1: Creating Race & Slavery
content.description: From indentured servitude to race-based slavery, Bacon's Rebellion, Atlantic slave trade

content.title: IC2: Rebellion & Resistance
content.description: Pueblo Revolt, Metacom's War, Stono Rebellion, enslaved people's resistance

content.title: IC3: Colonial Identity & Society
content.description: Great Awakening, consumer revolution, regional differences, Seven Years' War

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 key terms including race-based slavery, indentured servitude, Bacon's Rebellion, Middle Passage, Great Awakening, and more. 2 attempts, 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: People & Events
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 questions about key people (Nathaniel Bacon, Pop√©, George Whitefield, Olaudah Equiano) and events. 2 attempts, 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Timeline Builder OR Comparison Activity
activities.studentInstructions: Choose Timeline (sort events 1620-1763) or Comparison (analyze regional differences in colonial development). 2 attempts, 25 minutes.

modules.title: Revolution & New Nation
inquiryQuestions: How did colonists transform from proud British subjects to independence seekers in just one decade?
In what ways did popular protests reshape the Revolution from elite-led to broadly inclusive?
How did debates over federal power reveal fundamental disagreements about the nation's future?

mlos.text: Analyze the causes and consequences of the American Revolution
Evaluate how revolutionary rhetoric clashed with slavery and limited rights for women and Native Americans
Explain the debates over the Constitution and competing visions of federal power

content.title: IC1: Revolutionary Ideas & Causes
content.description: Imperial crisis, popular protest, Boston Massacre, Tea Party, road to independence

content.title: IC2: Revolutionary War & Experiences
content.description: Military conflict, African American participation, women's roles, Native American alliances

content.title: IC3: Creating a New Nation
content.description: Articles of Confederation, Constitutional Convention, Federalist/Anti-Federalist debates, Bill of Rights

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 terms including Stamp Act, Sons of Liberty, Constitutional Convention, Federalist Papers, and more. 2 attempts, 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: People & Events
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 questions about Samuel Adams, George Washington, Abigail Adams, James Madison, and key revolutionary events. 2 attempts, 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Timeline Builder OR Comparison Activity
activities.studentInstructions: Choose Timeline (sequence revolutionary events 1763-1800) or Comparison (analyze Federalist vs Anti-Federalist positions). 2 attempts, 25 minutes.

activities.title: LA4: Analyzing the Election of 1800
activities.format: Mixed Question Types (Categorization, Hotspot, Matching, Multiple Answer, Numeric)
activities.studentInstructions: Analyze historical data from the Election of 1800 including voting eligibility, electoral votes, and population statistics. View 3 detailed charts and answer 10 questions using various question types. 2 attempts, 35 minutes.

modules.title: Early Republic & Market Revolution
inquiryQuestions: How did Jefferson's democratic rhetoric align with his actual policies regarding race and Native sovereignty?
How did the War of 1812 transform American nationalism and Native resistance movements?
How did transportation and technology transform regional economies differently across North and South?

mlos.text: Evaluate Jeffersonian democracy and its contradictions
Analyze the causes and effects of the War of 1812 on American identity
Explain how the Market Revolution reshaped labor, family, and gender roles

content.title: IC1: Early Republic & Testing Revolutionary Ideals
content.description: Jeffersonian democracy, Louisiana Purchase, Embargo Act, War of 1812, Haitian Revolution impact

content.title: IC2: Market Revolution & Economic Transformation
content.description: Transportation revolution, Erie Canal, cotton gin, factory system, wage labor

content.title: IC3: Freedom Struggles & Reform Movements
content.description: Native resistance (Tecumseh), cult of domesticity, Panic of 1819

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 terms including Jeffersonian democracy, Louisiana Purchase, Market Revolution, cotton gin, cult of domesticity. 2 attempts, 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: People & Events
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 questions about Thomas Jefferson, Toussaint Louverture, Eli Whitney, Tecumseh, and key events. 2 attempts, 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Timeline Builder OR Comparison Activity
activities.studentInstructions: Choose Timeline (sort events 1800-1824) or Comparison (analyze Market Revolution's different impacts on North vs South). 2 attempts, 25 minutes.

modules.title: Jacksonian Democracy & Expansion
inquiryQuestions: How did expanding white male suffrage occur alongside systematic disenfranchisement of Black voters?
What does the Bank War reveal about competing visions of democratic power and economic justice?
How did westward expansion and Indian Removal reflect American ambitions and contradictions?

mlos.text: Analyze the expansion and limitations of Jacksonian democracy
Evaluate the impact of Indian Removal policies on Native American nations
Explain the political and economic consequences of the Bank War

content.title: IC1: Territorial Expansion & Indigenous Removal
content.description: Manifest Destiny, Indian Removal Act, Trail of Tears, Cherokee Nation resistance

content.title: IC2: Jacksonian Democracy & Political Transformation
content.description: Universal white male suffrage, Bank War, nullification crisis, second party system

content.title: IC3: Religious Awakening & Reform Movements
content.description: Second Great Awakening, utopian communities, early reform movements

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 terms including Manifest Destiny, Indian Removal Act, Trail of Tears, Bank War, nullification crisis. 2 attempts, 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: People & Events
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 questions about Andrew Jackson, John Ross, John C. Calhoun, and key events of the Jacksonian era. 2 attempts, 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Timeline Builder OR Comparison Activity
activities.studentInstructions: Choose Timeline (sequence events 1815-1840) or Comparison (analyze who gained vs lost rights in Jacksonian era). 2 attempts, 25 minutes.

modules.title: Reform & Social Movements
inquiryQuestions: How did evangelical revivals inspire Americans to pursue social reform movements?
Why did abolitionism prove so divisive compared to other reform movements?
How did women's participation in reform lead them to advocate for their own equality?

mlos.text: Analyze the connections between religious revival and social reform movements
Evaluate the strategies and divisions within the abolitionist movement
Explain how women's reform work led to the women's rights movement

content.title: IC1: Religious Fervor & Social Reform
content.description: Second Great Awakening, temperance, education reform, moral reform societies

content.title: IC2: Abolitionism & Resistance
content.description: Antislavery movement, gradualism vs immediatism, Black abolitionists, slave resistance

content.title: IC3: Women's Rights & Intersecting Reforms
content.description: Seneca Falls Convention, women reformers, connections between movements

activities.title: LA1: Key Terms & Concepts
activities.studentInstructions: Match 15 terms including temperance, abolitionism, Seneca Falls, American Anti-Slavery Society, and more. 2 attempts, 20 minutes.

activities.title: LA2: People & Events
activities.studentInstructions: Answer 10 questions about William Lloyd Garrison, Frederick Douglass, Elizabeth Cady Stanton, and reform movements. 2 attempts, 30 minutes.

activities.title: LA3: Timeline Builder OR Comparison Activity

activities.title: LA4: Analyzing Antebellum Reform Movements
activities.format: Mixed Question Types (Ordering, Multiple Answer, Categorization, Numeric, Matching)
activities.studentInstructions: Analyze historical data about reform movement growth, antislavery petitions, and women's participation. View 4 detailed charts and answer 10 questions. 2 attempts, 35 minutes.

modules.title: Sectional Crisis
inquiryQuestions: How did westward expansion transform slavery from a regional institution into a national crisis?
What role did Black activism play in escalating antislavery politics beyond compromise?
Why did the Republican Party's 1860 victory precipitate secession rather than negotiation?

mlos.text: Analyze how territorial expansion created irreconcilable sectional divisions
Evaluate the breakdown of political compromises from Missouri to Kansas-Nebraska
Explain how the 1860 election triggered the secession crisis

content.title: IC2: Compromises Under Strain

content.title: IC3: Fracture Accelerates

activities.title: LA2: People & Events

modules.title: Civil War
inquiryQuestions: How did the Civil War transform from a conflict to preserve the Union into a war for emancipation?
What role did enslaved people and free African Americans play in forcing this ideological shift?
How did the war reshape society, gender roles, and family structures across North and South?

mlos.text: Analyze the causes, course, and consequences of the Civil War
Evaluate how African Americans shaped the war's transformation into an emancipation struggle
Explain the social and economic impacts of the war on different populations
